article_title: Fewer Texans enrolling in health care exchange
article_text:
Fewer Texans enrolling in health care exchange

Photo: Steve Gonzales, Staff Secretary of Health and Human Services Sylvia Burwell confers with...

Forty percent fewer Texans signed up for coverage on the federally mandated health insurance exchange during the first month of open enrollment compared with a year ago, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services reported Wednesday.

article_metadata.description: Forty percent fewer Texans signed up for coverage on the federally mandated health insurance exchange during the first month of open enrollment compared with a year ago, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services reported Wednesday.  The sign-up period for coverage through Affordable Care Act's marketplace last year was slightly different, as open enrollment began on Nov. 15, 2014.  Karen Love, chief operating officer at Community Health Choice, a Houston managed care organization that offers health plans on the federal marketplace, said there could be another last-minute rush this year.  Just before enrollment began this year, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell lowered expectations, predicting a modest increase nationwide in 2016 of only about 1 million people.  [...] that the marketplace enrollment is in its third year, Moto said she believes many people, even those who have no tradition of buying health insurance, are becoming accustomed to the idea and importance of health care coverage.  Nationally, more than 16 million people have gained health insurance coverage since the Affordable Care Act went into effect.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam

og.description: Forty percent fewer Texans signed up for coverage on the federally mandated health insurance exchange during the first month of open enrollment compared with a year ago, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services reported Wednesday.  The sign-up period for coverage through Affordable Care Act's marketplace last year was slightly different, as open enrollment began on Nov. 15, 2014.  Karen Love, chief operating officer at Community Health Choice, a Houston managed care organization that offers health plans on the federal marketplace, said there could be another last-minute rush this year.  Just before enrollment began this year, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell lowered expectations, predicting a modest increase nationwide in 2016 of only about 1 million people.  [...] that the marketplace enrollment is in its third year, Moto said she believes many people, even those who have no tradition of buying health insurance, are becoming accustomed to the idea and importance of health care coverage.  Nationally, more than 16 million people have gained health insurance coverage since the Affordable Care Act went into effect.
